elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">In this study, nanotube arrays of nickel-phosphate have been developed by electroless deposition into sub-micro to nanometer sized pores of the porous alumina templates by hypophosphite electrolytic solution composed of NiSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, NaH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, NaC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> at 80–100 °C and pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>3–6. The dimension of the formed nanotubes has 1 μm in length, 200–300 nm in diameter and 80–150 nm in thickness of tube walls. Transmission electron microscopy examination of the nanotubes clearly show amorphous hallow structure with a average grain size of <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mo>∼</mml:mo>
<mml:mn>5</mml:mn>
<mml:mtext> </mml:mtext>
<mml:mtext>nm</mml:mtext>
</mml:math>. The hysteresis loops of the nanotube arrays show a coercive field of about 200 Oe under treatment in 95%N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/5%H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere at 500 °C as the magnetic field was applied along parallel and perpendicular to tube axis. The nanotube arrays also exhibit an anisotropic magnetic property with easier saturation along the perpendicular direction. However, both coercive field and saturation of remanent magnetization of the nanotube arrays become lower while continually increasing heat treatment temperature up to 900 °C.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this study, nanotube arrays of nickel-phosphate have been developed by electroless deposition into sub-micro to nanometer sized pores of the porous alumina templates by hypophosphite electrolytic solution composed of NiSO4, NaH2PO2, NaC2H3O2 and Na3C6H5O7 at 80-100°C and pH=3-6. The dimension of the formed nanotubes has 1 μm in length, 200-300 nm in diameter and 80-150 nm in thickness of tube walls. Transmission electron microscopy examination of the nanotubes clearly show amorphous hallow structure with a average grain size of  ~ 5   nm . The hysteresis loops of the nanotube arrays show a coercive field of about 200 Oe under treatment in 95%N2/5%H2 atmosphere at 500°C as the magnetic field was applied along parallel and perpendicular to tube axis. The nanotube arrays also exhibit an anisotropic magnetic property with easier saturation along the perpendicular direction. However, both coercive field and saturation of remanent magnetization of the nanotube arrays become lower while continually increasing heat treatment temperature up to 900°C.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all"></ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Magnetic film and nanowires have been the most interesting and intensely investigated fields of material in recent years . The fabrication of magnetic metal arrays has not only the fundamental worth in these materials but also their potential utilization in magnetic recording. For high density storage media, one single nanosized pattern, ordered nanodots or nanotubes is a single domain structure and denotes one bit signal. Magnetic period nanostructure arrays as an ultra-high-density magnetic storage can achieve recording densities of more than 100 Gbit/in<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which is more than the continuous magnetic film of 40 Gbit/in<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
. Arrays of ferromagnetic nonodots, nanowires or nanotubes may be fabricated by several methods such as e-beam lithography, imprint technology or template. The porous template can be considered as one quicker and cheaper method to prepare highly perpendicular magnetic anisotropy structure  because AAO (anodic aluminum oxide) has high oriented porous structure with uniform and nearly parallel pores that can be organized the pseudo ordered nanowires or nanotubes array. Such structure also shows high magnetic anisotropy phenomena with the shape axis parallel to the nanowire arrays.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract



Introduction

Magnetic film and nanowires have been the most interesting and intensely investigated fields of material in recent years . The fabrication of magnetic metal arrays has not only the fundamental worth in these materials but also their potential utilization in magnetic recording. For high density storage media, one single nanosized pattern, ordered nanodots or nanotubes is a single domain structure and denotes one bit signal. Magnetic period nanostructure arrays as an ultra-high-density magnetic storage can achieve recording densities of more than 100 Gbit/in2, which is more than the continuous magnetic film of 40 Gbit/in2 . Arrays of ferromagnetic nonodots, nanowires or nanotubes may be fabricated by several methods such as e-beam lithography, imprint technology or template. The porous template can be considered as one quicker and cheaper method to prepare highly perpendicular magnetic anisotropy structure  because AAO (anodic aluminum oxide) has high oriented porous structure with uniform and nearly parallel pores that can be organized the pseudo ordered nanowires or nanotubes array. Such structure also shows high magnetic anisotropy phenomena with the shape axis parallel to the nanowire arrays.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="gr001"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">On the other hand, it is well known that transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni and their alloy have higher saturation magnetization as well as Curie temperature, and lower crystalline anisotropy. Furthermore, magnetic properties are strongly influenced by the dimension and crystal properties, which also depend on the physical structure of templates and growth mechanism of wires or tubes. Recently, magnetic properties of nickel nanowires have been investigated by several groups because nickel nanowires show important applications in magnetic recording .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, it is well known that transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni and their alloy have higher saturation magnetization as well as Curie temperature, and lower crystalline anisotropy. Furthermore, magnetic properties are strongly influenced by the dimension and crystal properties, which also depend on the physical structure of templates and growth mechanism of wires or tubes. Recently, magnetic properties of nickel nanowires have been investigated by several groups because nickel nanowires show important applications in magnetic recording .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Compared with the electrodepositing method, electroless deposition needs neither power nor smooth interface. In this study, it was found that there exist some variation in nucleation rate from heterogeneities process and some defects are also induced in this process. By adjusting deposition, we have fabricated uniform size nanotube and nanowire arrays by autocatalytic electroless deposition in AAO. Furthermore, the effect of experimental conditions on the morphology of nanostructure will be discussed. The preliminary results of their magnetic properties are also reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compared with the electrodepositing method, electroless deposition needs neither power nor smooth interface. In this study, it was found that there exist some variation in nucleation rate from heterogeneities process and some defects are also induced in this process. By adjusting deposition, we have fabricated uniform size nanotube and nanowire arrays by autocatalytic electroless deposition in AAO. Furthermore, the effect of experimental conditions on the morphology of nanostructure will be discussed. The preliminary results of their magnetic properties are also reported.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental procedure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">High ordered AAO templates with pore diameter of about 50–200 nm were used from commercial porous alumina templates (Whatman 6809 7013). The electrolyte solution was prepared from NiSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.05 M), NaH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.04 M), NaC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.01 M) and Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (0.005 M). One side of AAO templates was sputtered with 200 nm Au film as catalytic layer. The coated template was first immersed in an aqueous solution and kept at low vacuum environment to enhance the solution into the pores. Subsequently, Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanowire arrays were deposited in the pores from the electrolyte solution at 80–95 °C and pH 3–6 adjusted by sulfuric acid and ammonia. For obtaining the isolated Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanowire arrays, the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P deposited AAO was dissolved in 5 wt% NaOH solution at 25 °C for 20 min and then slightly washed several time to remove the original AAO template.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental procedure

High ordered AAO templates with pore diameter of about 50-200 nm were used from commercial porous alumina templates (Whatman 6809 7013). The electrolyte solution was prepared from NiSO4 (0.05 M), NaH2PO2 (0.04 M), NaC2H3O2 (0.01 M) and Na3C6H5O7 (0.005 M). One side of AAO templates was sputtered with 200 nm Au film as catalytic layer. The coated template was first immersed in an aqueous solution and kept at low vacuum environment to enhance the solution into the pores. Subsequently, NiP nanowire arrays were deposited in the pores from the electrolyte solution at 80-95°C and pH 3-6 adjusted by sulfuric acid and ammonia. For obtaining the isolated NiP nanowire arrays, the NiP deposited AAO was dissolved in 5 wt% NaOH solution at 25°C for 20 min and then slightly washed several time to remove the original AAO template.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The microstructure and morphology were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The magnetic properties were measured by magnetometer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and energy dispersive spectra (EDS) are employed to study the morphology and chemical composition of nanotubes. The magnetic property of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes is characterized using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The microstructure and morphology were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The magnetic properties were measured by magnetometer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and energy dispersive spectra (EDS) are employed to study the morphology and chemical composition of nanotubes. The magnetic property of NiP nanotubes is characterized using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM).

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The redox reactions would take place spontaneously in electroless bath if total electrochemical potential  Δ  E 0   value is positive. The autocatalytic redox reactions of NiP nanotube arrays in an acid medium are shown in the following equations:    Ni (  H 2  O )  6  2 +   + 2  e -  → Ni + 6  H 2  O ,   E 0  = - 0.25   V ,        H 2   PO 2 -  +  HO 2  →  H 2   PO 3  + 2  H -  + 2  e -  ,   E 0  = - 0.5   V ,        H 2   PO 2 -  + 2  H -  + 2  e -  → P +  HO 2  ,   E 0  = - 0.25   V .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The <mml:math altimg="si6.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>E</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> represents the single electrode potential. If the <mml:math altimg="si7.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>E</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> value of a reducing reaction is lower than that of oxide reaction, the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P deposited reaction will possibly take place in electrolytic solution. According to the <mml:math altimg="si8.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>E</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> value, Ni and P could be reduced by NaH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2(aq)</ce:inf>. However, as a rule, these reaction could not proceed without catalyst. Therefore, Au film usually acts as a catalyst in the reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The   E 0   represents the single electrode potential. If the   E 0   value of a reducing reaction is lower than that of oxide reaction, the NiP deposited reaction will possibly take place in electrolytic solution. According to the   E 0   value, Ni and P could be reduced by NaH2PO2(aq). However, as a rule, these reaction could not proceed without catalyst. Therefore, Au film usually acts as a catalyst in the reaction.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig001"></ce:float-anchor> shows pH-potential of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O group and P<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O group at room temperature. Three stable regions of Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni and NiO are illustrated in Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O group: Ni keeps stable at low potential for any pH values. If potential increases (<mml:math altimg="si9.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mo>></mml:mo>
<mml:mo>−</mml:mo>
<mml:mn>0.25</mml:mn>
<mml:mtext> </mml:mtext>
<mml:mtext>V</mml:mtext>
</mml:math>), Ni will be oxidized as Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (at pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>6) or NiO (at pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>6). In pH-potential of P<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O group, it can be found that H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> group appears at pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>6 in acid region and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> group appear at pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>6 in alkaline region. It is clear to understand that Ni could be formed regardless of at acid and alkaline electrolytic bath. However, precipitated NiO is much easily formed in alkaline electrolytic bath so that it would be better to control the bath at the pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>6. Besides, while changing temperature and complex agent (NaC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>), pH-potential will be shifted but the tendency remains similar.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows pH-potential of NiH2O group and PH2O group at room temperature. Three stable regions of Ni2+, Ni and NiO are illustrated in NiH2O group: Ni keeps stable at low potential for any pH values. If potential increases ( > - 0.25   V ), Ni will be oxidized as Ni2+ (at pH<6) or NiO (at pH>6). In pH-potential of PH2O group, it can be found that H2PO2 H2PO3 group appears at pH<6 in acid region and H2PO2 HPO3 group appear at pH>6 in alkaline region. It is clear to understand that Ni could be formed regardless of at acid and alkaline electrolytic bath. However, precipitated NiO is much easily formed in alkaline electrolytic bath so that it would be better to control the bath at the pH<6. Besides, while changing temperature and complex agent (NaC2H3O2 and Na3C6H5O7), pH-potential will be shifted but the tendency remains similar.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">After removing the AAO in aqueous NaOH, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig002"></ce:float-anchor> shows the SEM image of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotube arrays formed in an electrolytic bath at 90 °C and pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>4.5. The nanotubes were estimated with the average dimension of 200–300 nm and length of about 2 μm. The TEM image of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes in c further shows that these nanotubes are uniform with the wall thickness about 40 nm and the corresponding electron diffraction pattern indicates it is an amorphous structure. So far, most of the investigations in the literature have demonstrated the solid nanowires structure can be developed via AAO template. However, in this work, the formation of the tube structure could be explained as follows. As the Au was sputtered into the pores, hollow structure could be formed as show in d. Next, the deposited Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P could cause preferring growth on the pore wall to form nanotubes. The energy disperse spectrometry analysis indicates that the nanotubes are composed of Ni and P (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig003"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: After removing the AAO in aqueous NaOH,   shows the SEM image of NiP nanotube arrays formed in an electrolytic bath at 90°C and pH=4.5. The nanotubes were estimated with the average dimension of 200-300 nm and length of about 2 μm. The TEM image of NiP nanotubes in c further shows that these nanotubes are uniform with the wall thickness about 40 nm and the corresponding electron diffraction pattern indicates it is an amorphous structure. So far, most of the investigations in the literature have demonstrated the solid nanowires structure can be developed via AAO template. However, in this work, the formation of the tube structure could be explained as follows. As the Au was sputtered into the pores, hollow structure could be formed as show in d. Next, the deposited NiP could cause preferring growth on the pore wall to form nanotubes. The energy disperse spectrometry analysis indicates that the nanotubes are composed of Ni and P ( ).

<ce:para view="all">The XRD patterns of 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig004"></ce:float-anchor>a further indicate that the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes exhibit amorphous structure with <mml:math altimg="si10.gif" overflow="scroll">

However, as the nanotubes were heated up to 500 °C in 95%N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/5%H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere, Nickel HCP phase was detected as shown in b. The grain size in the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes increases with increasing temperature. At 700 °C, the average grain size was estimated as 35 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The XRD patterns of  a further indicate that the NiP nanotubes exhibit amorphous structure with  ~ 5   nm  ultra-fine grains. However, as the nanotubes were heated up to 500°C in 95%N2/5%H2 atmosphere, Nickel HCP phase was detected as shown in b. The grain size in the NiP nanotubes increases with increasing temperature. At 700°C, the average grain size was estimated as 35 nm.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Moreover, it was found that different solution pH values in electrolytic bath result in the morphology change of the nanostructure. The wall of the nanotubes becomes thinner while increasing pH to 6 because the deposited rate will decrease under high pH value. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig005"></ce:float-anchor>a shows this kind of structure where many sheet residues appear due to the deposition of NiO. On the other hand, at lower pH value, i.e., 3, both reduction and deposition rate of metal ions in the electrolytic bath become faster at the bottom of the pore. Therefore, nanowires instead of nanotubes were grown along the pore channel to form a solid structure (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Moreover, it was found that different solution pH values in electrolytic bath result in the morphology change of the nanostructure. The wall of the nanotubes becomes thinner while increasing pH to 6 because the deposited rate will decrease under high pH value.  a shows this kind of structure where many sheet residues appear due to the deposition of NiO. On the other hand, at lower pH value, i.e., 3, both reduction and deposition rate of metal ions in the electrolytic bath become faster at the bottom of the pore. Therefore, nanowires instead of nanotubes were grown along the pore channel to form a solid structure (b).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig006"></ce:float-anchor> shows the hysteresis loop of the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes array measured at room temperature. The H(pl) and H(pd) represent external magnetic field parallel to Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes and perpendicular to Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes, respectively. While the sample was heated less than 300 °C, no clear hysteresis loop of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes array was detected as shown in a that might be related to the amorphous structure. As heating the sample up than 500 °C, a distinct hysteresis loop (b) begins to appear and this suggests the formation of crystalline structure. It would be also found that both saturation magnetization (Bs) and remanence (Br) of H(pl) are larger than those of H(pd). However, the coercive field (Hc) for H(pl) and H(pd) orientation are similar about 200 Oe. As compared with the Hc of Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanowires (800–1300 Oe), the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes array are more suitable for magnetic recording.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows the hysteresis loop of the NiP nanotubes array measured at room temperature. The H(pl) and H(pd) represent external magnetic field parallel to NiP nanotubes and perpendicular to NiP nanotubes, respectively. While the sample was heated less than 300°C, no clear hysteresis loop of NiP nanotubes array was detected as shown in a that might be related to the amorphous structure. As heating the sample up than 500°C, a distinct hysteresis loop (b) begins to appear and this suggests the formation of crystalline structure. It would be also found that both saturation magnetization (Bs) and remanence (Br) of H(pl) are larger than those of H(pd). However, the coercive field (Hc) for H(pl) and H(pd) orientation are similar about 200 Oe. As compared with the Hc of CoP nanowires (800-1300 Oe), the NiP nanotubes array are more suitable for magnetic recording.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The hysteresis loop also shows different magnetic anisotropy and this indicates that the easily magnetized direction is perpendicular to the nanotubes axis. Moreover, the arrays appear very low remanent magnetization less than 20% Bs. However, while continually increasing heat-treatment temperature up to 900 °C, both coercive field and saturation of remanent magnetization of the nanotube arrays become much lower. This indicates that magnetic anisotropy of the nanotube arrays gradually disappears under overmuch thermal effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The hysteresis loop also shows different magnetic anisotropy and this indicates that the easily magnetized direction is perpendicular to the nanotubes axis. Moreover, the arrays appear very low remanent magnetization less than 20% Bs. However, while continually increasing heat-treatment temperature up to 900°C, both coercive field and saturation of remanent magnetization of the nanotube arrays become much lower. This indicates that magnetic anisotropy of the nanotube arrays gradually disappears under overmuch thermal effect.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Electroless deposition with Au catalyst can be applied to fabricate Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P magnetic nanotube arrays by controlling electrolytic bath at 90 °C and pH<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>4.5–6. The studies indicate that the highly ordered array nanotubes are amorphous structure with the average diameter of 200–300 nm and length of 2 μm and form a highly ordered array. The hysteresis loop of the array nanotubes shows magnetic anisotropy with the easily magnetized direction perpendicular to the nanotubes axis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Electroless deposition with Au catalyst can be applied to fabricate NiP magnetic nanotube arrays by controlling electrolytic bath at 90°C and pH=4.5-6. The studies indicate that the highly ordered array nanotubes are amorphous structure with the average diameter of 200-300 nm and length of 2 μm and form a highly ordered array. The hysteresis loop of the array nanotubes shows magnetic anisotropy with the easily magnetized direction perpendicular to the nanotubes axis.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental procedure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">High ordered AAO templates with pore diameter of about 50–200 nm were used from commercial porous alumina templates (Whatman 6809 7013). The electrolyte solution was prepared from NiSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.05 M), NaH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.04 M), NaC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.01 M) and Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (0.005 M). One side of AAO templates was sputtered with 200 nm Au film as catalytic layer. The coated template was first immersed in an aqueous solution and kept at low vacuum environment to enhance the solution into the pores. Subsequently, Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanowire arrays were deposited in the pores from the electrolyte solution at 80–95 °C and pH 3–6 adjusted by sulfuric acid and ammonia. For obtaining the isolated Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanowire arrays, the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P deposited AAO was dissolved in 5 wt% NaOH solution at 25 °C for 20 min and then slightly washed several time to remove the original AAO template.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental procedure

High ordered AAO templates with pore diameter of about 50-200 nm were used from commercial porous alumina templates (Whatman 6809 7013). The electrolyte solution was prepared from NiSO4 (0.05 M), NaH2PO2 (0.04 M), NaC2H3O2 (0.01 M) and Na3C6H5O7 (0.005 M). One side of AAO templates was sputtered with 200 nm Au film as catalytic layer. The coated template was first immersed in an aqueous solution and kept at low vacuum environment to enhance the solution into the pores. Subsequently, NiP nanowire arrays were deposited in the pores from the electrolyte solution at 80-95°C and pH 3-6 adjusted by sulfuric acid and ammonia. For obtaining the isolated NiP nanowire arrays, the NiP deposited AAO was dissolved in 5 wt% NaOH solution at 25°C for 20 min and then slightly washed several time to remove the original AAO template.

processes.working electrode: AAO templates with 200 nm Au film

The dimension of the formed nanotubes has 1 μm in length, 200–300 nm in diameter and 80–150 nm in thickness of tube walls. Transmission electron microscopy examination of the nanotubes clearly show amorphous hallow structure with a average grain size of <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

The nanotube arrays also exhibit an anisotropic magnetic property with easier saturation along the perpendicular direction. The nanotubes were estimated with the average dimension of 200–300 nm and length of about 2 μm. The TEM image of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes in c further shows that these nanotubes are uniform with the wall thickness about 40 nm and the corresponding electron diffraction pattern indicates it is an amorphous structure. So far, most of the investigations in the literature have demonstrated the solid nanowires structure can be developed via AAO template. The grain size in the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes increases with increasing temperature. At 700 °C, the average grain size was estimated as 35 nm.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig006"></ce:float-anchor> shows the hysteresis loop of the Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes array measured at room temperature. The H(pl) and H(pd) represent external magnetic field parallel to Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes and perpendicular to Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes, respectively. While the sample was heated less than 300 °C, no clear hysteresis loop of Ni<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>P nanotubes array was detected as shown in a that might be related to the amorphous structure. As heating the sample up than 500 °C, a distinct hysteresis loop (b) begins to appear and this suggests the formation of crystalline structure. It would be also found that both saturation magnetization (Bs) and remanence (Br) of H(pl) are larger than those of H(pd). However, the coercive field (Hc) for H(pl) and H(pd) orientation are similar about 200 Oe. The hysteresis loop of the array nanotubes shows magnetic anisotropy with the easily magnetized direction perpendicular to the nanotubes axis.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this study, nanotube arrays of nickel-phosphate have been developed by electroless deposition into sub-micro to nanometer sized pores of the porous alumina templates by hypophosphite electrolytic solution composed of NiSO4, NaH2PO2, NaC2H3O2 and Na3C6H5O7 at 80-100°C and pH=3-6. The dimension of the formed nanotubes has 1 μm in length, 200-300 nm in diameter and 80-150 nm in thickness of tube walls. Transmission electron microscopy examination of the nanotubes clearly show amorphous hallow structure with a average grain size of  ~ 5   nm . The hysteresis loops of the nanotube arrays show a coercive field of about 200 Oe under treatment in 95%N2/5%H2 atmosphere at 500°C as the magnetic field was applied along parallel and perpendicular to tube axis. The nanotube arrays also exhibit an anisotropic magnetic property with easier saturation along the perpendicular direction. However, both coercive field and saturation of remanent magnetization of the nanotube arrays become lower while continually increasing heat treatment temperature up to 900°C.

After removing the AAO in aqueous NaOH,   shows the SEM image of NiP nanotube arrays formed in an electrolytic bath at 90°C and pH=4.5. The nanotubes were estimated with the average dimension of 200-300 nm and length of about 2 μm. The TEM image of NiP nanotubes in c further shows that these nanotubes are uniform with the wall thickness about 40 nm and the corresponding electron diffraction pattern indicates it is an amorphous structure. So far, most of the investigations in the literature have demonstrated the solid nanowires structure can be developed via AAO template. However, in this work, the formation of the tube structure could be explained as follows. As the Au was sputtered into the pores, hollow structure could be formed as show in d. Next, the deposited NiP could cause preferring growth on the pore wall to form nanotubes. The energy disperse spectrometry analysis indicates that the nanotubes are composed of Ni and P ( ).

The XRD patterns of  a further indicate that the NiP nanotubes exhibit amorphous structure with  ~ 5   nm  ultra-fine grains. However, as the nanotubes were heated up to 500°C in 95%N2/5%H2 atmosphere, Nickel HCP phase was detected as shown in b. The grain size in the NiP nanotubes increases with increasing temperature. At 700°C, the average grain size was estimated as 35 nm.

   shows the hysteresis loop of the NiP nanotubes array measured at room temperature. The H(pl) and H(pd) represent external magnetic field parallel to NiP nanotubes and perpendicular to NiP nanotubes, respectively. While the sample was heated less than 300°C, no clear hysteresis loop of NiP nanotubes array was detected as shown in a that might be related to the amorphous structure. As heating the sample up than 500°C, a distinct hysteresis loop (b) begins to appear and this suggests the formation of crystalline structure. It would be also found that both saturation magnetization (Bs) and remanence (Br) of H(pl) are larger than those of H(pd). However, the coercive field (Hc) for H(pl) and H(pd) orientation are similar about 200 Oe. As compared with the Hc of CoP nanowires (800-1300 Oe), the NiP nanotubes array are more suitable for magnetic recording.

Conclusion

Electroless deposition with Au catalyst can be applied to fabricate NiP magnetic nanotube arrays by controlling electrolytic bath at 90°C and pH=4.5-6. The studies indicate that the highly ordered array nanotubes are amorphous structure with the average diameter of 200-300 nm and length of 2 μm and form a highly ordered array. The hysteresis loop of the array nanotubes shows magnetic anisotropy with the easily magnetized direction perpendicular to the nanotubes axis.
